Polynomial maps with nilpotent Jacobians in dimension three I

Dan Yan 111 The author are supported by the Natural Science Foundation of Hunan Province (Grant No.2016JJ3085), the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No.11601146) and the Construct Program of the Key Discipline in Hunan Province.

Abstract

In this paper, we first prove that u,v,h𝑢𝑣ℎu,v,h are linearly dependent over 𝐊𝐊{\bf K} if J​H𝐽𝐻JH is nilpotent and H𝐻H has the form: H=(u​(x,y,z),v​(u,h),h​(x,y))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑣𝑢ℎℎ𝑥𝑦H=(u(x,y,z),v(u,h),h(x,y)) with H​(0)=0𝐻00H(0)=0 or H=(u​(x,y),v​(u,h),h​(x,y,z))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑢ℎℎ𝑥𝑦𝑧H=(u(x,y),v(u,h),h(x,y,z)) with H​(0)=0𝐻00H(0)=0. Then we classify polynomial maps of the form H=(u​(x,y),v​(x,y,z),h​(x,y))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑧ℎ𝑥𝑦H=(u(x,y),v(x,y,z),h(x,y)) in the case that J​H𝐽𝐻JH is nilpotent and (degy⁡u,degy⁡h)≤2subscriptdegree𝑦𝑢subscriptdegree𝑦ℎ2(\deg_{y}u,\deg_{y}h)\leq 2.

Keywords. Jacobian Conjecture, Nilpotent Jacobian matrix, Polynomial maps

1 Introduction

Throughout this paper, we will write 𝐊𝐊{\bf K} for algebraically closed field and 𝐊​[X]=𝐊​[x1,x2,…,xn]𝐊delimited-[]𝑋𝐊subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛{\bf K}[X]={\bf K}[x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{n}] (𝐊​[X¯]=𝐊​[x,y,z]𝐊delimited-[]¯𝑋𝐊𝑥𝑦𝑧{\bf K}[\bar{X}]={\bf K}[x,y,z])for the polynomial algebra over 𝐊𝐊{\bf K} with n𝑛n (333) indeterminates. Let F=(F1,F2,…,Fn):𝐊n→𝐊n:𝐹subscript𝐹1subscript𝐹2…subscript𝐹𝑛→superscript𝐊𝑛superscript𝐊𝑛F=(F_{1},F_{2},\ldots,F_{n}):{\bf{K}}^{n}\rightarrow{\bf{K}}^{n} be a polynomial map, that is, Fi∈𝐊​[X]subscript𝐹𝑖𝐊delimited-[]𝑋F_{i}\in{\bf{K}}[X] for all 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n. Let J​F=(∂Fi∂xj)n×n𝐽𝐹subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗𝑛𝑛JF=(\frac{\partial F_{i}}{\partial x_{j}})_{n\times n} be the Jacobian matrix of F𝐹F.

The Jacobian Conjecture (JC) raised by O.H. Keller in 1939 in [8] states that a polynomial map F:𝐊n→𝐊n:𝐹→superscript𝐊𝑛superscript𝐊𝑛F:{\bf{K}}^{n}\rightarrow{\bf{K}}^{n} is invertible if the Jacobian determinant detJ​F𝐽𝐹\det JF is a nonzero constant. This conjecture has been attacked by many people from various research fields, but it is still open, even for n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2. Only the case n=1𝑛1n=1 is obvious. For more information about the wonderful 70-year history, see [1], [5], and the references therein.

In 1980, S.S.S.Wang ([10]) showed that the JC holds for all polynomial maps of degree 2 in all dimensions (up to an affine transformation). The most powerful result is the reduction to degree 3, due to H.Bass, E.Connell and D.Wright ([1]) in 1982 and A.Yagzhev ([12]) in 1980, which asserts that the JC is true if the JC holds for all polynomial maps X+H𝑋𝐻X+H, where H𝐻H is homogeneous of degree 3. Thus, many authors study these maps and led to pose the following problem.

(Homogeneous) dependence problem. Let H=(H1,…,Hn)∈𝐊​[X]𝐻subscript𝐻1…subscript𝐻𝑛𝐊delimited-[]𝑋H=(H_{1},\ldots,H_{n})\in{\bf K}[X] be a (homogeneous) polynomial map of degree d𝑑d such that J​H𝐽𝐻JH is nilpotent and H​(0)=0𝐻00H(0)=0. Whether H1,…,Hnsubscript𝐻1…subscript𝐻𝑛H_{1},\ldots,H_{n} are linearly dependent over 𝐊𝐊{\bf K}?

The answer to the above problem is affirmative if rankJ​H≤1𝐽𝐻1JH\leq 1 ([1]). In particular, this implies that the dependence problem has an affirmative answer in the case n=2𝑛2n=2. D. Wright give an affirmative answer when H𝐻H is homogeneous of degree 3 in the case n=3𝑛3n=3 ([11]) and the case n=4𝑛4n=4 is solved by Hubbers in [7]. M. de Bondt and A. van den Essen give an affirmative answer to the above problem in the case H𝐻H is homogeneous and n=3𝑛3n=3 ([3]). A. van den Essen finds the first counterexample in dimension three for the dependence problem ([6]). M. de Bondt give a negative answer to the homogeneous dependence problem for d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3. In particular, he constructed counterexamples to the problem for all dimensions n≥5𝑛5n\geq 5 ([2]). In [4], M. Chamberland and A. van den Essen classify all polynomial maps of the form H=(u​(x,y),v​(x,y,z),h​(u​(x,y),v​(x,y,z)))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑧ℎ𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑧H=(u(x,y),v(x,y,z),h(u(x,y),v(x,y,z))) with J​H𝐽𝐻JH nilpotent. In particular, they show that all maps of this form with H​(0)=0𝐻00H(0)=0, J​H𝐽𝐻JH nilpotent and H1,H2,H3subscript𝐻1subscript𝐻2subscript𝐻3H_{1},H_{2},H_{3} are linearly independent has the same form as the counterexample that gave by A. van den Essen in [6] (up to a linear coordinate change). We classify all polynomial maps of the form H=(u​(x,y),v​(x,y,z),h​(x,y,z))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑧ℎ𝑥𝑦𝑧H=(u(x,y),v(x,y,z),h(x,y,z)) in the case that J​H𝐽𝐻JH is nilpotent and degz⁡v≤3subscriptdegree𝑧𝑣3\deg_{z}v\leq 3, (degy⁡u​(x,y),degy⁡h​(x,y,z))=1subscriptdegree𝑦𝑢𝑥𝑦subscriptdegree𝑦ℎ𝑥𝑦𝑧1(\deg_{y}u(x,y),\deg_{y}h(x,y,z))=1 ([13]).

In section 2, we prove that u,v,h𝑢𝑣ℎu,v,h are linearly dependent over 𝐊𝐊{\bf K} if J​H𝐽𝐻JH is nilpotent and H𝐻H has the form: H=(u​(x,y,z),v​(u,h),h​(x,y))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑣𝑢ℎℎ𝑥𝑦H=(u(x,y,z),v(u,h),h(x,y)) with H​(0)=0𝐻00H(0)=0 or H=(u​(x,y),v​(u,h),h​(x,y,z))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑢ℎℎ𝑥𝑦𝑧H=(u(x,y),v(u,h),h(x,y,z)) with H​(0)=0𝐻00H(0)=0. Then, in section 3, we classify all polynomial maps of the form H=(u​(x,y),v​(x,y,z),h​(x,y))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑧ℎ𝑥𝑦H=(u(x,y),v(x,y,z),h(x,y)) in the case that J​H𝐽𝐻JH is nilpotent and (degy⁡u​(x,y),degy⁡h​(x,y))≤2subscriptdegree𝑦𝑢𝑥𝑦subscriptdegree𝑦ℎ𝑥𝑦2(\deg_{y}u(x,y),\deg_{y}h(x,y))\leq 2 or degy⁡u​(x,y)subscriptdegree𝑦𝑢𝑥𝑦\deg_{y}u(x,y) or degy⁡h​(x,y)subscriptdegree𝑦ℎ𝑥𝑦\deg_{y}h(x,y) is a prime number. In Theorem 3.11, we prove that u,v,h𝑢𝑣ℎu,v,h are linearly dependent over 𝐊𝐊{\bf K} if J​H𝐽𝐻JH is nilpotent and H𝐻H has the form: H=(u​(x,y),v​(x,y,z),h​(x,y))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑧ℎ𝑥𝑦H=(u(x,y),v(x,y,z),h(x,y)) with H​(0)=0𝐻00H(0)=0 and u𝑢u is homogeneous. The main results in the paper are Theorem 2.4, Theorem 2.6, Theorem 3.3, Theorem 3.5 and Theorem 3.11. We define Qxi:=∂Q∂xiassignsubscript𝑄subscript𝑥𝑖𝑄subscript𝑥𝑖Q_{x_{i}}:=\frac{\partial Q}{\partial x_{i}} and that degy⁡fsubscriptdegree𝑦𝑓\deg_{y}f is the highest degree of y𝑦y in f𝑓f.

Remark 2.2.

If H​(0)≠0𝐻00H(0)\neq 0, then it easy to compute that there exists H=(u,v,h)𝐻𝑢𝑣ℎH=(u,v,h) such that u,v,h𝑢𝑣ℎu,v,h are linearly independent and J​H𝐽𝐻JH is nilpotent: H=(u​(y),c,h​(x,y))𝐻𝑢𝑦𝑐ℎ𝑥𝑦H=(u(y),c,h(x,y)) with c≠0𝑐0c\neq 0, u​(y)∈𝐊​[y]/𝐊𝑢𝑦𝐊delimited-[]𝑦𝐊u(y)\in{\bf K}[y]/{\bf K} and h​(x,y)∈𝐊​[x,y]/𝐊​[y]ℎ𝑥𝑦𝐊𝑥𝑦𝐊delimited-[]𝑦h(x,y)\in{\bf K}[x,y]/{\bf K}[y].

Corollary 2.3.

Let H=(u​(h),v​(x,y,z),h​(x,y))𝐻𝑢ℎ𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑧ℎ𝑥𝑦H=(u(h),v(x,y,z),h(x,y)) be a polynomial map with H​(0)=0𝐻00H(0)=0. If J​H𝐽𝐻JH is nilpotent, then u,v,h𝑢𝑣ℎu,v,h are linearly dependent.

Proof.

Let

Corollary 3.9.

Let H=(u​(x,y),v​(x,y,z),h​(x,y))𝐻𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑧ℎ𝑥𝑦H=(u(x,y),v(x,y,z),h(x,y)) be a polynomial map over 𝐊​[x,y,z]𝐊𝑥𝑦𝑧{\bf K}[x,y,z]. If degy⁡u=3subscriptdegree𝑦𝑢3\deg_{y}u=3 or degy⁡h=3subscriptdegree𝑦ℎ3\deg_{y}h=3, then the conclusion follows from Theorem 3.3. If degy⁡q=0subscriptdegree𝑦𝑞0\deg_{y}q=0 or 1 or 2, then the conclusion follows from the proof of Theorem 3.5.
